Carcassonne: The Discovery is a strange variant of the game. Here the tension is in when you choose to score your meeples, and you only have 4. After placing a tile you can add a meeple to it OR retrieve a previously placed meeple to score it. It becomes even more crucial to do this before the end of the game because scoring of uncollected meeples is done as if they are incomplete. The flow of the game is therefore quite different to a more conventional Carcassonne. #bgg #boardgames

Another epic game of Roll for the Galaxy (with the Alien ORB). It finished at 99-98 in my favour. The Alien Uplift Explorers was the first development I built, which did slow me down but then it steadily escalated with each subsequent settlement of Green or Yellow worlds which of course I focussed on. The only disappointment was the starting Genetic Psychics who should have been able to make use of the vast numbers of green dice I accumulated but I just couldn‚Äôt find any 6+ developments. Raphael meanwhile had virtually every Terraforming development imaginable and was able to settle 3 worlds in the final turn to almost overturn my lead.  #bgg #boardgames #rollforthegalaxy

Yesterday we tried out The Ming Voyages by #surprisedstaregames and I ended up as the Barbarian Overlord, winning on the last play of the game. The Ming certainly seem to have a harder time of it, having to gather gold, build fleets, and go on voyages, as well as trying to prevent themselves being overrun by barbarians ‚Äî who just have to amass hordes and pour across the border.  I suspect it will take a couple of turns to figure out how to use the Ming special abilities to their advantage.

caption: Apparently LG stands for Life‚Äôs Good. Or Let‚Äôs Go?

I subscribed to an actual physical magazine for the first time in absolutely ages. The chosen title was the second coming of the Wisden Cricket Monthly ‚Äî a periodical I used to subscribe to in the 80s, and had (for a while) every single issue. It is fascinating to see how it has addressed the changed environment we live in now. The old WCM would devote at least 1/3 of the contents to match reports and other statistics. The new one has none at all, though to be honest this could be because of the pandemic! They did have some photos from the first Test match between England and West Indies at Southampton earlier this month, but perhaps they will have reports next month. The focus is much more on good articles on all aspects of the game rather than scorecards, which, of course, you can get online easily these days. Back in the 80s, in far away New Zealand, the magazine was an authoritative source of scores and statistics, along with its small format sibling, the Cricketer Quarterly.
Ex-special-branch.

caption:
It seems amazing now, when we are overrun with boardgames containing lots of custom figures and shaped wooden tokens, to harken back to 2007 and the arrival of Agricola. It came in a hefty box, with dozens of cards but just a great heap of wooden cubes and discs to represent resources and player markers. A sensation in Germany, pent up demand for an English version meant that people bought the German version and used laminated paste ups as overlays and even for the cards, with (very well done) translations by fans. I got one of these paste-ups (and then the English version when it was released of course). But people wanted more. They were not satisfied with cubes for sheep, pigs and cattle and rumours started to swirl around about supplying wooden shapes instead, swiftly dubbed ‚Äúanimeeples‚Äù. Others couldn‚Äôt wait and started to brighten up their copies by making animals from Fimo or similar modelling clay. I had a go but was extremely poor at it, then I was lucky to score a complete set in a maths trade from an enthusiast who had made two complete sets and put one up for trade. For the period when Agricola ruled the roost we used these wonderful creations all the time. Now as well as starting a legendary line of continuously refined Uwe Rosenberg variations on farming/mining themes, Agricola could be said to have helped initiate the evolution of cubes into cute custom shapes! A landmark game.
#bgg #boardgames #agricola #animeeples

Over the last 7 weeks, as part of the nationwide For the Love of Scrubs initiative, my wife Rosie has been organising a local team which has now grown to almost 100 participants. She has drafted patterns, sourced the fabric, marked up and cut out thousands of pieces to make ready made kits for people to sew at home. So far nearly 800 kits have been created. But there are still more needed, as well as hospital staff, care homes and GPs now need scrubs as well. So if you have a spare bit of cash, please consider supporting this (or similar efforts). caption: A game underlining the importance of card draw. I had no card draw at all, never found a single project offering it, and the Colony that lets you draw cards wasn‚Äôt in play. Raphael built out a vast tableau with multiple engines, including all sorts of card draw. He also had insane titanium production with Advanced Alloys. Scoring was 100-100 after scoring the board and resources on cards. Then it went downhill as I had all of 5 points on cards compared to his 51. Comprehensively defeated. #bgg #boardgames #terraformingmars

comments.text: Absolutely superb game and also fickle with player opportunities and shut outs. I just keep playing and playing and playing as a regression toward the mean.
@drewwrites indeed. It‚Äôs still fun to crank the engine even when you‚Äôre having bad luck with draft.
This is one of the reasons I always draft.
@harlaquinne astonishingly this was a draft game. I just had astoundingly bad luck.

Yeah. You are completely right. There‚Äôs so much to say about this topic in TM ! In the base game, since the biggest way to earn points is the board, you may not realise the power of card draw and of science. But since you add expansions, you really understand why card draw is the most powerful way to win a game. Yeah of course you have to build your productions and to make your economy snowball in the first gens, that‚Äôs why there are prelude and colonies, but after, using the board isn‚Äôt enough when there are big animal engines, much more jovian tags to earn points.... Btw the player getting IA central wins 9 games out of 10 because 2 free cards each turn is just bullshit. Moreover, another thing that TM players have to accept is that sometimes the game just doesn‚Äôt let you have the first place, sometimes it just doesn‚Äôt give the cards you need, and it happens, it‚Äôs an adaptation game, and you can still aim for the second place or for scoring as much as you can ! Anyway, always fun to draw a lot of cards, I had a fun games in which I was drawing around 10 cards per turn since I had a colony + research colony on Pluto to draw cards... that‚Äôs also why r√©duction on the cards‚Äô price is broken, and that‚Äôs why earth catapult or research outpost are way too strong in my opinion

caption: Thanks to prompting by @gilhova my deck building cricket game is now (hidden) on Tabletop Simulator. Almost ready to try out! #bgg #boardgames

comments.text: Are we building a team or a partnership? Either good!

@mikesiggins Two players, one as batting team and one as bowling team. Swap about (obvs.) after first innings over. Both attempt to improve their deck to be able to score runs, increase form (for BAT) or take wickets, and bother the batter (for BOWL) while trying to avoid accumulating FATIGUE. Innings stops after fall of 5th wicket because by then the bowler should have the wherewithal to run through the tail quickly which isn‚Äôt very interesting. Can also just set an arbitrary target for a 1 innings game if time is short.
@christophertd Sounds very interesting. Count me in for a test.
@mikesiggins Sure thing. I just need to get a walkthrough with TTS so I am familiar with how that works.

For the first half of the game we consistently only rolled 1 on the production die, and therefore neither of us could travel far in the sectors and had strange feast/famine on resources. It did force us to play slightly unusual strategies, and in the end despite a mid game surge from me, Raphael was able to get the winning point the turn before I would have. For an old game in a small box we sure have had a lot of mileage from this one.

Achievement Unlocked! I have completed the Pok√©dex in #PokemonSword on the #NintendoSwitch. This meant I had to capture and register 400 different varieties of Pokemon, which involved a number of strategies, including hatching eggs, wonder trades and special trades with friends to evolve specific types. Even stranger niche activities included spinning on the spot while a Pokemon held a specific sweet, holding the Switch upside down while one levelled up and walking under an arch in the evening with an unhealthy Pokemon. I got to 399 out of the 400 required by Tuesday, and on Wednesday they launched Pokemon Home, which, amongst other things, lets you transfer Pokemon from earlier games, so I was able to transfer Mawile, a not particularly unusual Pokemon, but which had nevertheless eluded me, to complete the Pok√©dex. In a few months some additional expansion content will add another 200 or so to the Pok√©dex so I can start all over again!

Oh dear. Accidentally launched Final Fantasy Tactics on the iPad Pro, and found myself starting a new game. For a game created in 1997 this stands up remarkably well, and is probably my favourite game ever. The controls are a bit freaky on the iPad but manageable and the game itself is simply superb. So despite all the new shiny in Apple Arcade, and titles like Civ VI in reserve, alongside a Switch Lite stuffed with new games, FFT is what I will be spending my time with for the short term!

Of course it was the Mother Spore which did for the Farmhand leaving the Forgehand to despatch it with 1 health remaining. Much time was used up recovering from this, only to encounter Goblin Shamans (Shamen?) in the next location and get reduced to 1 health again. At least the locations had a healthy population of the icons we were looking for. The time deck was pretty depleted by the time the adventurers lurched into the next two locations to conclude their search for wildlife. A Druach‚Äôs way is a hard one! Top tip ‚Äî don‚Äôt be CARELESS.  #bgg #boardgames

The highlight of yesterday was definitely Quartermaster General, a game I have been one footstep away from joining on many occasions, but this was the first time that I played. It needs 6 people so Chris, Kris, Jeff, Jean-Francois, Debbie and Matt were recruited as generals by Jeff and it was every bit as rewarding as I expected. Russia and Japan swooped back and forth across the Asia/Pacific region while the European powers engaged in more static activity, favouring careful Status card play. But once Japan overreached in India it started to go better for the good guys! I really enjoyed the experience, exactly the level of conflict style game that I can manage. #bgg #boardgames

And we did get Up Front to the table for ‚ÄúU‚Äù in the alphabetical #bgg challenge. I taught Oscar how to play, in the introductory scenario and was once again reminded that this game always generated a terrific narrative, and a lot of tension. My guys floundered around in a Stream for a long time, finally escaping directly into a Marsh. Eventually we regrouped in time to thwart his advance, but it was pretty close. I wonder how difficult it would be to learn from scratch now, and whether I would bother, especially as straight up wargames have little appeal for me now. Many fond memories of extended Up Front sessions though. #boardgames

This is a truly great wargame

We played a *ton* of this in the 80s; I remember returning to it in the late 90s and feeling a little disenchanted. Especially in the core game, the US and Soviets are so constrained by lousy morale and hand capacity respectively that playing them can often feel a bit tedious if you just don‚Äôt have the right cardflow, whereas the Germans with their alway-discard-one hand rarely face tough hand management choices. The British and Japanese in the expansion seem to be more reliably engaging. I‚Äôve never tried some things like the variant US squad with 2 BARs that apparently are a bit more interesting.

And yeah, the rules really are bonkers. But OTOH, lots of people have tried to take the Up Front idea and implement it at a lower complexity level, and it‚Äôs never worked out well. So maybe all that complicity really is needed.

When the list of options appears, scroll down until you see ‚Äú3D Photo‚Äù. Select that and you‚Äôll see a list of your portrait photos (standard photos won‚Äôt appear). Select a good one (like this one) and enjoy. Unfortunately, you can‚Äôt share that photo anywhere else. But you can then view it on the iPad (even though you could only share the photo from the iPhone). It‚Äôs a very cool effect.

comments.text: I think it is a bit easier to manage that T&E. The inter-kingdom conflicts in T&E were very tricky, a *lot* of points could be at stake and it was easy to get them wrong and give those points away until you got comfortable with the game. The conflict system in Y&Y is lower-stakes points-wise and easier to manage. It‚Äôs still painful to get them wrong, but it‚Äôs easier and you‚Äôre not going to give away the game if you do.
@cfarrell317 great news. I recall conflicts going spectacularly wrong in T&E for sure.

The Eyrie were wise to sit out this one. We attempted to take on the Mechanical Marquise with the Woodland Alliance and the Vagabond. It was a dismal failure, we did manage to force it back a bit but could never have collected 30 VP each. #bgg #boardgames

comments.text: A copy I found on BGG should be arriving tomorrow. I'm pretty excited.

Defeating the Mechanical Marquise is very difficult - especially with the Alliance. The Alliance‚Äôs power curve is a slow early burn followed by an explosive endgame. The Mechanical Marquise you have to be relentless in beating it back right from the start, not letting it get established. You‚Äôve gotta have the Eyrie to have any kind of chance I think - the Alliance is really in trouble because of their slow early game, and the Vagabond isn‚Äôt helping much. Maybe try the Lizard Cult.

@cfarrell317 yes. This has matched our (somewhat limited) experience. The Eyrie can get beaks on the ground and start pushing them back. Two complete mega recruits in first two turns pretty much sealed our doom this time though.

comments.text: Awesome..
Which game is this? Looks great!

@straycarnivore it's a small card game called The Grizzled. From BGG description: The Grizzled is a cooperative game about survival in the trenches during the first World War where players win or lose together.

Each round, the current team leader will choose how many cards every player draws. Then, going around the table, players must either play a card in their hand or back out of the mission. Each card represents either threats to the team (such as mortar shells and weather conditions) or negative personality traits (such as frightened or obsessive). At the end of the round, more cards are added to the draw deck. The game ends only if the players can deplete the draw deck as well as their hands without letting time run out.
@christophertd sold!

I have performed an unauthorised hack on my AirPods using some foam covers purchased specially for the princely sum of ¬£1 a dozen. I did exhume some vintage Apple foam covers, probably from the original iPod. They were still sealed in the plastic pouch they were delivered in but were so fragile they simply fell apart when touched. The hack requires melting 4 small holes in the foam covers so that the sensors on the AirPods still work. With their foam jackets on the AirPods sit more firmly in the ear, dramatically improving the sound. To be clear they were never in danger of falling out of my ears but they are so slippery they shifted ever so slightly causing the ‚Äúideal‚Äù fit to be lost. The strange green tinge is because I used a green Sharpie to mark the spots to make my (extremely unsurgical) incisions.
#airpods

By golly the region was a mess at the end but we won with no outbreaks to spare and one card in the deck, on the last possible turn. Used Scientist, Agronomist and Rural Doctor. Tense and engaging as always. #bgg #boardgames #pandemiciberia

comments.text: Wow.

@cfarrell317 and there were two more cities with 3 cubes down the Atlantic coast, just off the picture. It took Second Chance to retrieve Toledo after the building of the final hospital on my turn, then Jack scooted up the railway to take the card and research  Black.

Holy cow, that's totally out of control! I don't know that I've ever seen a game of Pandemic with so many disease cubes out on the board where you still managed to pull out the win. Must have been riding the knife's edge for a while üò≥!
Been really enjoying Iberia. Hopefully they can keep doing cool things with the brand. I hear there's a Holland version coming along, but with flooding instead of disease.

@cfarrell317 the final epidemic came quite early so we knew we just had to manage stuff for last 4 turns but we got lucky with water purification choices. Had to guess where to protect and it was 50:50 whether we triggered game end outbreak! We built lots of rail too which helped in the end. I really like this version too, just a tad more control or at least the illusion of it!

@thomasnoppers request an archive of your tweets from your twitter profile page and after a short time they email a link to download. That unzips to a local file structure that when you load in your browser includes that graph.

comments.text: Do you have the original photo üòÄ ?
üé∂üé∂brave sir thaddeus ran away üé∂üé∂
@simpike not yet. This is vague recollect again. With spurious added sword for drama.
Wow! Truly great, Christopher. This is my favorite work of yours yet. Considering this was done on an iPad, 'm especially impressed by the finely detailed the hatching. ‚ù§Ô∏è
@originalspooky thanks Frank! Yes. Hatching is hard on iPad because the stroke doesn't vary. Also add random nature of my hatching! I was pleased with this picture too though.

I understand that the iPad is kind of your thing, but I really think you should try pen and paper sometime. I think you'd be surprised to discover how good you'd be at it. I could be wrong, but believe it would suit your particular drawing style especially well.
@originalspooky I will give it a go at some point. I do quite a bit of rubbing out so I may need robust paper!

It's true that the lack of undo with ink is a bit unnerving. Sometimes I wing it completely, draw directly in pen and just live with the mistakes (like yesterday's fair attendee). When I'm feeling less bold, I'll draw lightly in pencil (erasing and redrawing), go over it in permanent ink, then erase liberally to eliminate the pencil drawings. That's the approach I took with the Raven, because I wanted to get the Raven's silhouette just right. If you keep going at this rate, folks are going to want to buy your work. And you may want to hang onto your iPad. üòÄ

I think what happened is that the phone slipped down as we went over potholes and the grippy bars on the car mount touched the power button and triggered it. Holding out in the woods, my sole remaining leader helps me secure a clutch victory against the Red scourge. Really quite enjoyed the introductory scenario of Command & Colours: Samurai Battles. With each variant of the system it takes a while to understand the strengths and weaknesses of the various unit, and leaders are terribly fragile in this one. The Dragon cards add to the narrative nicely and C&C games are often strong there already, as the cards push you in interesting directions. #bgg #boardgames

caption:
Another couple of bouts of Up Front against @cfarrell317 on #tabletopsimulator, which is surprisingly playable. I do need to practice picking one card off a deck though. I also forgot to take a screen shot of the dramatic denouement of the first bout so had to mock it up for real. I was in a strong position with one Russian squad pinned and their group A reduced to one man, Private Petrovsky. But he had acquired a demo charge from a successful close combat and in a glorious Hail Mary move he flung it into the building where my main squad was. Game over. For a game that abstracts away much of the normal trappings of a war game this was surprisingly sticky, terrain wise, My Group A advanced through Brush, Brush and into a Building. Then retreated back through Brush while the Petrovsky crowd advanced into, you guessed it, a Building. All very tidy, narrative wise. After all these years it retains all the things I used to like about it, as well as the problematic ones, including the theme, which, let‚Äôs face it, isn‚Äôt farming‚Ä¶
#bgg #boardgames #upfront

Twenty years old this year and we are still perfectly happy to play this. Sure, it is comfort food by now, but comfort food still has to have reasons for its staying power. A nice mix of exploration, ship building and resource gathering, all within a short playing time. Before Dice by PCALC (@stresspanda) in the realm of amazingly over-engineered dice toys there was DICECARDS by Ian Millington, which had 40 different randomisers, all on a pack of cards. There was an iOS app briefly, now lost in the mists of time.

caption: Neighbourhood Watch

Backups used to be a very kinetic and noisy activity, especially in the day of backing up to dozens of floppy disks. Then Bernoulli and Jaz disks were also pleasantly industrial in the scurrying and fwisking noises they made as they worked. Even little USB HDDs made light whirrings. @peterhaslehurst it‚Äôs totally pared back to exploring a maze of 100 floors with minimal story, almost no graphics, but strong mechanisms. Figuring out how things work is part of the game. It‚Äôs really very good, nicely paced and pleasantly finite. Having said that there are map and math riddles that are sometimes obscure and I looked those up rather than try to solve. This didn‚Äôt diminish it for me as they were not very many.

So having squeaked through the Elite Four with a scratch party containing 3 passengers, I foolishly saved the game, thinking I could probably also cope with the Champion. WRONG. She is much tougher, especially if your party is woefully unbalanced. Still, we thought it might be possible and we managed to cheese our way through, with some outrageously silly tactics, including running her Milotic out of PP, then readying Gengar with X Speed to inflict TOXIC on her Garchomp and try to outlast it. As it happened she used a Full Restore, but Mew was able to hold on for the win. Not so much a difficulty spike as a difficulty mountain. Fun to puzzle it out though. #pokemon #pokemonbdsp
I think, on balance, this is the most underwhelming Microfighter kit of them all. #lego #starwars #microfighters

caption:
But what of Boardgames you ask? Well, Raphael and I played a lot of Terraforming Mars during 2021, 37 times to be precise. I must be a glutton for punishment because he won 28 of them. The list you see above also contains a few games I played against an AI, in my ultimately misguided challenge to myself to play 10 games 10 times on the iPad. The only one I finished 10 times was Wingspan, some of the others turned out to be too intense to tackle in a year when my brain spent a lot of time befogged.

New games to us during the year included Cubitos, an excellent racing game involving cheeses in lederhosen, and other strange things; Imperium Classics and Legends, a very interesting take on Civ style games with excellent solo mode; Llamaland, a fun little puzzle game of laying out lands to attract llamas; and The Siege of Runedar, a thoroughly excellent co-op game by Reiner Knizia.
#bgg #boardgames

Getting ready for the relay

Morning everyone, on the back of her work at the Scrubbery Rosie was nominated and unbelievably selected to be a baton bearer in The Queen‚Äôs baton relay which is a journey of 7,500 runners across the Commonwealth. Her uniform has arrived and she carries the baton 1.5 miles tomorrow morning starting at the Olympic Bell in the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park near Stratford (9:30). There were 8000 nominations and 2022 people from all over the United Kingdom and Ireland selected to run. 
The baton has been designed with a 360 degree camera in it to record what the runner sees - it also records the heart beat of the runner. Looks really beautiful and Rosie feels honoured. Hurrah!

Container of the day. Fun fact: One of my first computing jobs involved tracking containers as they made their way around the Pacific Ocean. This didn‚Äôt involve GPS tracking of course, we received telex messages with container numbers on them from the ships and via an RS-232 interface read these into our program. We then had to validate the container number with a special container checksum algorithm.
